So, for those of you who may not be
familiar, the story process
traditionally is um where we turn the
written script into an actual visual
animated show. Um, and specifically, we
create an animatic. And an animatic is
basically a blueprint for the entire
episode where decisions about shots and
timing and composition and performance
are all figured out in advanced in a
kind of rough format so that we can send
it to our partner studios for uh
complete production.
In traditional CG shows, the animatic is
fully drawn by storyboard artists. And
what follows that boarding phase then uh
is a process that typically becomes the
responsibility of the vendor studio,
which is uh where those boards are
translated into 3D in a process called
layout. Now, because we had very
specific ideas about how we wanted to
use our cameras, translation, we were
very, very picky. we needed that 3D
layout information to be part of our

full control over the visual look of the

were able to make that possible.
